body: THE bicycle swung wide left under Alexander Barouh as he furiously pedaled to the end of his 500-meter sprint, bringing gasps from the crowd standing only a few feet from his front wheel. ''Don't steer!'' some spectators in the Lower East Side bar shouted. As he struggled to steady himself, a large red arrow spun behind him, tracking his progress
title: SPOKES; Racing in Bars, Going Nowhere Fast

body: Affluent foreigners are rushing to take advantage of a federal immigration program that offers them the chance to obtain a green card in return for investing in construction projects in the United States. With credit tight, the program has unexpectedly turned into a mainstay for the financing of these projects in New York, California, Texas and
title: Rules Stretched As Green Cards Go to Investors

body: Four prolific writers -- Paul Theroux, Jeffrey Zaslow, Randall Silvis and Roberto Bola√±o -- are joined by two first-timers: a comic novelist and the nonfiction chronicler of a New York religious community. MURDER IN MOUNT HOLLY By Paul Theroux 148 pages. Mysterious Press. $22. Certain character types are overindulged in literature: the manly man,
title: Newly Released

body: When Alice Reiser, 89, wants to talk to her husband and sons, she turns to their photographs. They are all she has left of them, besides memories. ''I wake up every morning and say: 'Hello. Good morning,' '' Ms. Reiser said, using a cane to balance herself as she paused before a large picture on her living room wall of her younger son, Steven, at
title: NEEDIEST CASES; A Widow's Loneliness After Burying Her Children

body: Leironica Hawkins recalls always having ''social problems, sensory issues and bouts of depression,'' while growing up in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, as well as behavioral tics like self-rocking and involuntary hand twitches. Finally, at age 28, she was given a diagnosis: Asperger's syndrome, a form of autism, for which she has never received
title: CHARACTER STUDY; She Finds Refuge in Art

body: Click to read the updated version of this article that appears in the newspaper. Updated 12:02 p.m. | The collection of tarps and tents went up in the northern part of Foley Square late on Thursday, flanked by the State Supreme Court building to the east and the federal building to the west. There were placards decrying war and greed. There was a
title: CITY ROOM; 'Law & Order: SVU' Imitation Occupation Draws Real Protesters, and City's Ire

body: In the first part of a two-step effort at weeding out some of the poorest-performing schools, the Education Department announced on Thursday that it would move to close 12 of New York City's struggling schools and eliminate middle school grades at three others. Additional schools recommended for closing -- by one account, as many as 10 more -- will
title: 12 With Low State Test Scores Are Put on School Closing List

body: 'Fantasia on the Loose' On Sunday a striking blond celebrity with lots of curves will emerge from her New York home and languorously greet her many adoring young fans. It's not Scarlett Johansson. Meet Fantasia, the albino Burmese python at the Brooklyn Children's Museum. Unlike many famous New Yorkers, she'll allow her admirers to touch her and
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Devon Moore heard the news on Wednesday morning, and he was disgusted. But not surprised. When Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. was indicted for a second time, accused again of soliciting bribes in exchange for official favors -- in part to pay his legal fees from the first trial -- longtime residents of Brownsville, one of Brooklyn's most
title: A Lawmaker Back in Trouble, in a District That Knows Despair

body: She had to miss her father's funeral in Jamaica last year because she could not afford to go. Fresh fruits and vegetables are now a luxury. She keeps her hair short, cutting it herself to avoid the expense. Her only new clothing in more two years has been a dress her sister paid for and a $25 blouse she bought for an interview. These are the
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Out of Work, And Trying To Stay Positive

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com
body: In the aftermath of the Occupy Wall Street eviction from Zuccotti Park, a mayoral aide e-mailed reporters. The aide, Stu Loeser, said that he had heard of journalists ''supposedly'' wearing police press badges who ''allegedly encountered problems on the streets of New York.'' As I sling nouns and verbs for a living, I almost admired his artful
title: GOTHAM; Reporters Meet the Fists Of the Law

body: Charles Smith has a plan to make sure someone will always be around to take care of his son Cie-Jay, 7. In the event of Mr. Smith's death, Cie-Jay would live with Mr. Smith's ex-wife, the mother of his three older children. If she became ill, his oldest daughter would step in. If she were unavailable, an elderly aunt of Mr. Smith's would take up
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After a Killing, Cancer and Financial Problems, Trying to Ensure His Son's Happiness

body: The Bloomberg administration set in motion on Friday a broad contingency plan for a school bus drivers' strike, sending letters to parents and principals and buying hundreds of thousands of MetroCards for students who could be left without transportation. But a statement by the union's president indicated that the timing of a strike, if one were to
title: City Plans For Strike By Drivers Of Buses

body: 'AKC MEET THE BREEDS' The setup may remind you of speed dating or a matchmaking service. But here, at least, you can expect lifelong commitment. Not to mention unconditional love. Those aren't empty promises at ''AKC Meet the Breeds,'' the annual event to help families get acquainted with prospective companions of the furry, four-legged variety.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: THE signs seemed to point toward the end of Occupy Wall Street. The day after the city stripped the protesters encamped in Lower Manhattan of their generators and fuel, the Northeast was hit with a bone-chilling snowstorm that blanketed their tents and tarps with sleet and ice, and left at least one protester hospitalized for hypothermia. Yet the
title: A Protest Reaches a Crossroads

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg, who has defended the free-speech rights of Occupy Wall Street protesters while objecting to their message, said Wednesday that he had become more concerned about how the Occupy Wall Street encampment in Zuccotti Park was affecting residential and commercial life in Lower Manhattan. Hours after his remarks, the police
title: CITY ROOM; Mayor Says Protest Hurts Life in Area Around Park

body: Michael R. Bloomberg, Edward I. Koch and David N. Dinkins spoke Tuesday at a breakfast event in Midtown Manhattan. Here are some highlights: Accomplishments MR. KOCH ''Having rallied the people of the city of New York during the transit strike.'' MR. DINKINS Preserving six-day-a-week library service; Nelson Mandela's 1990 visit to the city; the
title: Leaders Reflect On Highs and Lows

body: NEW YORKERS have been fleeing Manhattan in search of more affordable housing for so long that just about every neighborhood in the other boroughs has been anointed the city's next great destination for bargains. Despite this well-worn path off the island, however, finding a place to live in some up-and-coming corner of the city can have its
title: Step Away From the Computer

body: HALLOWEEN SPOOKTACULAR No one would deny that high school can have distressing, scary and even hair-raising moments. But the fearsome classroom episodes about to unfold in Jersey City have nothing to do with neglected Latin declensions or forgotten math theorems. And those zombies at the desks? They're not just sleep-deprived adolescents. Welcome
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: $4.75 MILLION 555 Kingston Avenue (at Rutland Road) Crown Heights, Brooklyn A local family has bought this 30,400-square-foot 1927 four-story walk-up with 42 apartments. There are 34 one-bedrooms, 7 two-bedrooms and 1 three-bedroom. Buyer: Kingston Heights L.L.C. Seller: Kingston Court L.L.C. Broker: Aaron Jungreis, Rosewood Realty Group e-mail:

body: Kelly Lynn Kocinski, a daughter of Sharon L. Voris of Pierceton, Ind., and Dennis C. Kocinski of St. John, Ind., was married Saturday in Las Vegas to Josiah Samuel Trager, the son of Roberta E. Weisbrod of Brooklyn and the late Judge David G. Trager. The ceremony, at the Four Seasons Hotel, was led by Elena M. Paul McDonald, a friend of the bride
title: Kelly Kocinski, Josiah Trager

body: IT may not be Bergdorf's, as its owner likes to joke. But the competitive shopping at casaBAN -- an antiques store far from Fifth Avenue, in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn -- is just as fierce. I walk by the shop occasionally, and its window display has come to seem like a cruel magic trick. One day, an Indonesian stool stood front and center,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | BEDFORD-STUYVESANT; A Taste For Modern In Antiques

body: Assemblyman Hakeem Jeffries, calling Congress a ''swamp of dysfunction,'' has begun accepting contributions for a race against a fellow Democrat, Representative Edolphus Towns of Brooklyn. Mr. Jeffries said he had not made a final decision to run against Mr. Towns, but in late September he filed paperwork that would allow him to proceed as a
title: Assemblyman Appears Ready to Join Race for Congress

body: For Truffle Hounds White truffle season is starting in Italy, and among the best deals in a tasting menu showered with shavings of the precious fungus are the Tuesday evening menus, four courses, $60, at Sapori d'Ischia, 55-15 37th Avenue (56th Street), Woodside, Queens, (718) 446-1500. Wines from the Piedmont region to accompany the menu are also
title: Calendar

body: Dan Aymar-Blair -- age 36, suit wearer, resident of Crown Heights, Brooklyn -- never expected to find himself at a protest. Neither did Sean Aiken, a 35-year-old D.J. from Greenpoint, Brooklyn, whose interest in politics had mostly involved grumbling with his friends. The last time Peter Linard, 71, a retired waiter who lives on the Upper East
title: New to This Sort of Thing, Or at Least Long Dormant

body: Any taxi-riding, bodega-shopping, laundromat-using New Yorker knows that immigrants own many of the businesses that make New York tick. Now a new study shows that while immigrants constitute just over a third of the city's population, they make up nearly half of the city's small-business owners. The study, published Monday by the Fiscal Policy
title: Immigrants Play Key Role As Entrepreneurs in City

body: Kirsten John Foy says that everything happens for a reason -- and that the reason he and a black New York City councilman, Jumaane D. Williams, were briefly detained by the police at a parade on Sept. 5 was to call attention to racial bias in policing. But the event also had a secondary effect: It pushed Mr. Foy, a charismatic former aide to the
title: City Aide in Spotlight After Being Detained

body: CROWN HEIGHTS TWO-FAMILY $925,000 BROOKLYN: 931 St. Marks Avenue (Kingston and Albany Avenues) An 1896 Renaissance Revival limestone house divided into a four-bedroom two-and-a-half-bath triplex and a one-bedroom one-bath ground-floor unit. The house, in a cul-de-sac, has new mechanicals, a landscaped backyard, and parking in front. Barbara
title: On The Market

body: In the beginning, there was Public School 1. Then it got messy. There are actually four P.S. 1's in New York City: That first school, established in 1806 and later named for Alfred E. Smith (Manhattan); the Courtlandt School (the Bronx); the Bergen (Brooklyn); and the Tottenville (Staten Island). Plus, of course, the P.S. 1 in Long Island City,
title: Naming a Public School in New York? It Isn't as Simple as 1, 2, 3

body: A bystander who was fatally shot on a Brooklyn stoop may have been killed by a police officer's errant round, ballistics testing indicated on Wednesday. The 9-millimeter handgun that investigators say one man used to kill another on a street in Crown Heights on Monday has been eliminated as the source of a bullet that fatally struck the bystander,
title: Fatal Shot On a Stoop May Be Tied To the Police

body: Denise Gay had lived her entire life in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and most everyone on the block seemed to know the woman, just as she knew them. On Monday night, she sat on her stoop on Park Place, west of the elevated tracks for the Franklin Avenue subway shuttle. She waved to passers-by, enjoying what remained of Labor Day but mindful of the
title: On Her Stoop for Summer's Last Caress, Until Gunfire Erupts on Violent Weekend

body: Three people were fatally shot and two New York City police officers were wounded on Monday night in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. One of the victims was a bystander, a 56-year-old woman, sitting on a stoop near where the violence errupted. The shootings followed a weekend rife with gun violence. More than 30 people were wounded by firearms in the city
title: 2 Are Shot to Death and Officer Is Wounded

body: NEW YORK CITY UNICYCLE FESTIVAL Most of us spend a good part of our lives navigating the world on wheels: three when we're little, two when we're older, and of course the ubiquitous four. But only the truly skilled can get around on just one. Those extraordinary talents will have their day -- actually three -- this weekend, when the New York City
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: The New York City subway, whose closure in the lead-up to Tropical Storm Irene was perhaps the most unsettling element of a prodigious storm preparation effort, reopened on a limited schedule on Monday morning. Nearly all of the subway's 22 lines, including express and local service, have restored, according to the Metropolitan Transportation
title: New York Subway Plans Limited Morning Service; Commuter Lines Hobbled

body: STEVE SIDDELL paid just $700 a month for his share of the rent on a three-bedroom apartment in Crown Heights. But, at age 32, he felt too old to have roommates. Besides, one of his roommates was allergic to cats, so Mr. Siddell kept his two cats and their litter box in his bedroom, which necessitated installing a door sweep and two air purifiers.
title: THE HUNT; The Post-Roommate Stage

body: ANDREA KIDD often gets puzzled looks when she tells people she spends her summer weekends playing netball. ''I have to explain that it's like basketball, but you can't dribble with the ball, and our baskets have no backboards,'' said Ms. Kidd, 36, a Jamaican immigrant who plays defense for Pivot, a team in the Caribbean American Netball
title: SWEAT; The Sisterhood Of Netball

body: In the three months that the city and a good portion of the world buzzed about the hotel housekeeper and the French man of power, voices big and small spoke up for one side or the other, or simply urged that justice be found in a courtroom. There were news conferences, rallies, protests, cable-TV exhortations. But one New York staple has been
title: Assault Case Spurs Debate, But Sharpton Stays Silent

body: Lionel Mendoza, 54, a truck driver from the Bronx, flaunted his bodybuilder's physique on Saturday and said, ''You could say this body was literally built by the streets of New York City.'' Mr. Mendoza does not lift weights. He prefers to work out on city sidewalks doing pull-ups, dips and other calisthenics on any handy piece of street apparatus.
title: At These Neighborhood Bars, the Focus Is on Fitness

body: A sport utility vehicle driven by Assemblyman William F. Boyland Jr. was hit by gunfire in Brooklyn on Wednesday evening as he rode with his 7-year-old son, a police spokeswoman said. Neither Mr. Boyland nor his son was injured, said the spokeswoman, Deputy Inspector Kim Royster of the New York Police Department. Inspector Royster said Wednesday
title: Assemblyman's Vehicle Is Hit by Gunfire in Brooklyn, but He Is Unharmed

body: WALK into the modest railroad-style brownstone apartment and it feels less like Brooklyn and more like stepping off the steam train into ''Little House on the Park Slope Prairie.'' Floppy felt hats with broad rims gather like old friends on an antique green rack, greeting visitors at the door. Simple striped yellow, white and gray curtains adorn
title: Back to the Simple Life, With Needle and Thread

body: LIKE many New Yorkers, Alan Tansey is planning an escape this summer -- in his case, a 370-mile journey north through New York State, over the Canadian border and into the heart of Montreal. But unlike the hordes who brave highway traffic or airport lines to break free of the city, Mr. Tansey will start enjoying himself as soon as he lugs his
title: SPOKES | SEAN PATRICK FARRELL; Bike Vacations Offer Freedom and Frugality

body: THE art-fashion crowd struck a cool pose at the opening party for ''On Shuffle,'' an indie rock-themed show at the Lehmann Maupin Gallery in Chelsea. Kim Gordon of Sonic Youth nonchalantly stepped around her installation, a circle of glitter on the floor. Cecilia Dean, a founder of the avant-garde fashion bible Visionaire, sailed in wearing a black
title: The Art of Being a Character

body: NASHVILLE -- Tennessee's latest woes include high unemployment, continuing foreclosures and a battle over collective-bargaining rights for teachers. But when a Republican representative took the Statehouse floor during a recent hearing, he warned of a new threat to his constituents' way of life: Islamic law. The representative, a former fighter
title: Behind an Anti-Shariah Push

body: A stream of hospital administrators, a state assemblyman, doctors and advocates for immigrants took the microphone at a sometimes raucous hearing in Downtown Brooklyn on Thursday to plead with state officials not to close, merge or shrink troubled hospitals in the borough. The advocates identified at least 5 of the 17 hospitals in the borough --
title: Hospitals In Brooklyn Defended At Hearing

body: 'THE LITTLE FARM SHOW' Only a brave woman would denounce a McDonald's meal in a room full of children. But that's what Tannis Kowalchuk will do on Sunday at the Living Room, where she and Brett Keyser will perform ''The Little Farm Show.'' Children don't often consider where their food comes from, Ms. Kowalchuk said, ''and I want to propose that
title: Spare Times

body: ''Candelabras,'' said Serge Becker in an excited whisper. He was eyeing the onstage additions awaiting Alicia Keys at Joe's Pub, the intimate supper club at the Public Theater of which he is part owner. It was a Tuesday evening, and the club, which will soon close for renovations, was packed to the rafters with trembling female fans. As Mr. Becker
title: UP CLOSE; At the Twilight of Night Life

body: When the city officially recognized Douglaston Hill in Queens as a historic district in 2004, the community celebrated. Three years later, residents of Dumbo, Brooklyn, breathed a sigh of relief when their neighborhood, too, finally won its historic designation. With landmarking, the neighborhoods' buildings would be protected by the city and all
title: CITY ROOM; A Long Wait for Historic-District Signs

author: Sharon Otterman covers New York City public education for The Times.
body: There will be no courses at the Relay Graduate School of Education, the first standalone college of teacher preparation to open in New York State for nearly 100 years. Instead, there will be some 60 modules, each focused on a different teaching technique. There will be no campus, because it is old-think to believe a building makes a school.
title: Pedagogical Puzzle

body: When day broke on Wednesday in Borough Park, Brooklyn, the swarms of volunteers went home defeated, and the detritus of a frantic 36-hour search for a missing boy lay strewn by the curb. There were plastic water jugs, napkins and fliers outside the brick apartment building where Leiby Kletzky and his family lived on 15th Avenue, in the heart of the
title: After Coming Together for a Frantic Search, a Community Is Left Reeling

body: $5 MILLION 1580-1588 President Street (between Troy and Schenectady Avenues) Crown Heights, Brooklyn This 43,920-square-foot four-story walk-up, built in 1916, has 48 apartments: 16 one-bedrooms, 16 two-bedrooms, 8 three-bedrooms and 8 four-bedrooms. Rents average $874. Buyer: 1580 President L.L.C. Sellers: JK President L.L.C. and Dorchester Realty

body: JOE LEVIN, a private investigator in Brooklyn, was waiting to meet a new client in the parking lot of a kosher supermarket in Borough Park one recent morning. Glancing in the side-view mirror of his chauffeured sport utility vehicle, Mr. Levin said he liked this particular spot because he knew the manager, the delivery man and the security guard,
title: The Private Eye Wears a Skullcap

body: Fred Newman's influential role in New York life and politics defied easy description. He founded a Marxist-Leninist party, fostered a sexually charged brand of psychotherapy, wrote controversial plays about race and managed the presidential campaign of Lenora Fulani, who was both the first woman and the first black candidate to get on the ballot in
title: Fred Newman, 76, Writer And Postmodern Marxist

body: Jeffrey T. Kern had been impressed with the quiet young woman from Brooklyn, a businesslike student who always sat in the back of his class on courtroom communication at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. She was, Mr. Kern said on Thursday, ''a little bit above the fray, and when she did speak, it carried more weight.'' One day after class, the
title: Student's Shocking Revelation to a Professor

body: On a recent Sunday morning, Bruce Mauro let his girlfriend and two daughters assume he was heading out for his usual routine of playing the organ at church. Instead, he was taking care of some unfinished childhood business: he was learning to ride a bike. ''It's the first secret I ever kept from them,'' said Mr. Mauro, a music teacher and an
title: A Goal Met Before Age 50, And No Training Wheels!

author: Maurice Isserman is the James L. Ferguson professor of history at Hamilton College and the co-author, with Michael Kazin, of ''America Divided: The Civil War of the 1960s.''
body: WITNESS TO AN EXTREME CENTURY A Memoir. By Robert Jay Lifton. Illustrated. 428 pp. Free Press. $30. Apparently not. Lifton, whose academic affiliations include stints at the City University of New York, Yale and, most recently, Harvard, has devoted himself to studying how individuals have coped with extreme circumstances: war, torture, genocide. In
title: Dr. Hiroshima

body: From the moment George Zoulis woke up on Wednesday, sweat sticking between him and his bedspread, he knew he was in for a long day. ''Heat like this, customers get a little cranky,'' said Mr. Zoulis, 31, serving kabobs from his food cart on East Fordham Road in the Bronx at 1 p.m. Mr. Zoulis's regulars were among many New Yorkers reluctant to
title: Hot Enough to Exasperate, Since It's Technically Spring

body: WHEN the 10-year-old son of Brooke Garber Neidich, a chairwoman at the Whitney Museum, was having difficulty in school, there was only one person who was able to give him a proper diagnosis: Dr. Harold Koplewicz. When Debra G. Perelman, a daughter of the Revlon chairman Ronald O. Perelman, wanted to address her young daughter's social anxiety,
title: When a Child's Anxieties Need Sorting

body: GREAT ADAPTATIONS For the under-18 crowd summer movies usually mean big aliens, big guns and even bigger explosions. But the creators of a new film series at the Museum of the Moving Image have been deliberately thinking small, choosing works rooted not in the ever-expanding digital world but in the old-fashioned printed page. Called Great
title: Spare Times

body: In Coney Island, he was known as ''the rabbi.'' With his thick white beard and pointy mustache, muscled biceps and faded white tank top, Abraham Novitsky, better known as Rabbi Abraham Abraham, did not have a traditional congregation. His synagogue, people who knew him liked to say, was the beach, where he had been a fixture on the Boardwalk and on
title: Coney Island Bids Farewell To 'the Rabbi' of the Beach

body: This week the Weekend Miser columnist turns her cost-cutting attention to matters athletic. EVERY year, come spring, I want to do only two things: get back in shape and fall in love. The falling-in-love part could be a little tricky, but the getting in shape should be easy. And cheap. So six weeks ago I renounced the gym and set out to create a
title: URBAN ATHLETE; Tough on Bodies, Easy on Wallets

body: METROPOLITAN Because of an editing error, the City Critic column last Sunday about community gardens misspelled the surname of the manager of a small farm started by the High School for Public Serv- ice in Crown Heights, Brooklyn. She is Elizabeth Bee Ayer, not Ayers.
title: Corrections

body: 'ODD DAY RAIN' If you think children spend too much time with computers today, imagine their lives in 200 years. That's exactly what Janine Nina Trevens and Deirdre Broderick have done in ''Odd Day Rain,'' a new musical from Tada! Youth Theater. A science-fiction story that unfolds in what looks like a barren, post-apocalyptic landscape, the show
title: Spare Times

body: Art Museums and galleries are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Greatly expanded listings, as well as full reviews of recent shows, are available at nytimes.com/arts. body: SPOTTING a Borsalino, a black wide-brimmed felt fedora, in the traditionally Jewish section of Williamsburg, Brooklyn, is no strange thing. What was surprising was the wearer: Theophilus London, a hip-hop artist from Trinidad. ''This one is from the Jewish store,'' Mr. London said, motioning toward southern Williamsburg, where the haredi still
title: NOTICED; Culture Hopping In a Fedora

body: Five Myles 558 St. Johns Place, Crown Heights, Brooklyn Through May 8 Off the beaten art world path in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, with no budget and a leaky roof, the alternative space called Five Myles has been producing polished, offbeat shows for more than a decade. ''Art/Sewn: Tradition, Innovation, Expression'' is the latest. The guest curator,
title: ART IN REVIEW; 'Art Sewn': 'Tradition, Innovation, Expression'

body: Greenwich Village, May 1 Seven residences, ranging from a 19th-century townhouse where Emily Post once lived to a 350-square-foot apartment, will be open from 1 to 5:30 p.m. for the 13th annual event to benefit the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation. The tour will also include an Italianate home with an elaborately paneled entrance
title: New York City Home and Garden Tours

body: They called him ''Dirt'' -- and said it with affection. Playing in a recreational football league in the 1970s, his teammates recall, Dennis M. Walcott was a walking laundry-detergent commercial, constantly making tackles. During one game, as he pulled himself to his feet after sacking the quarterback, an opponent sucker-punched him in the jaw. The
title: In City's New Schools Chief, A Knack for Quiet Conciliation

body: EARTH DAY AT THE NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN While many children will hunt for Easter eggs this weekend, those visiting the New York Botanical Garden on Friday will seek other treasures. These won't have anything to do with candy or the Easter Bunny, though a rabbit might appreciate the leafier discoveries. ''They can find plants used by the ancient
title: Spare Times

body: Everyone knows that some of the best people-watching in New York City can be had in Hell's Hundred Acres. Those on the hunt for a middle-class complex would be well advised to check out the Gas House District. Hankering for bagels and a schmear? Get thee to Bloomingdale, stat. All are names, gone and widely forgotten, of the areas currently known
title: ProCro, SoBro, FiDi, BoCoCa: A Lawmaker Says, 'Enough'

body: A green thumb is a vital attribute for David W. Daly, a vegetarian with a passion for sustainable agriculture and an appetite for nasturtiums. Mr. Daly, 27, has been the coordinator at the half-acre children's garden at Brooklyn Botanic Garden since July 2009, where he plays a kind of hybrid role as both teacher and farmer. He lives within biking
title: ENTRY LEVEL; Raising Vegetables in an Edible Schoolyard

body: M. WELLS 21-17 49th Avenue (21st Street), Long Island City, Queens; (718) 425-6917, mwellsdiner.com. The restaurant opened last summer, the brainchild of a French Canadian chef, Hugue Dufour, and his Queens-raised wife, Sarah Obraitis. Mr. Dufour had cooked and been a partner at Au Pied de Cochon, a Montreal restaurant that is the subject of
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: In the Hasidic enclave of Crown Heights, Brooklyn, there are many things that women can't or just don't do: Be counted as one of the 10 people needed to make up a minyan, or prayer quorum. Walk around in pants. But vote? According to the bylaws of the Crown Heights Jewish Community Council, a social service agency and community pillar that has
title: For Jewish Community Council in Brooklyn, It's All-Women-No-Vote

body: Lisa S. Dozier was 7 when she saw her first dead body. She and her father had driven from Brooklyn to South Carolina for the funeral of a great uncle, Timothy, who had died in a reclining chair in his home. When Ms. Dozier got there, the funeral home workers had not yet arrived and she ignored her family's admonition to stay away from the body.
title: In Her Childhood Dream, a Funeral Home Was the Destination

body: THE fitness fanatic in Columbus Circle flaked. So did the performance-artist couple in Greenpoint who said they practiced at-home nudity. Yet Kenya Robinson's odyssey as a serial house guest has been smooth enough so far, and by and large her hosts -- friends, colleagues and total strangers -- have been happy to share their toothpaste with her. Ms.
title: The Serial Sleepover Artist

body: VIDEO Devorah Benjamin runs an organization in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, that plans and pays for weddings for couples who cannot afford them. She has raised over $5 million for 4,000 weddings. nytimes.com/cityroom
title: ONLINE

body: 629 Classon Avenue at Pacific Street, Crown Heights, Brooklyn, (718) 857-9227. In this desolate section of Crown Heights, not much meets the eye after dark. A gas station and a flats-fixed shop stand sentry at one end of the block, graffiti-scarred security gates and Dumpsters dominate the other. Yet eagle-eyed restaurant spotters, ever alert for a
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; Thirstbaravin

body: ON Friday afternoons, the headquarters of the Chabad sect of Orthodox Judaism comes alive as men in black jackets and hats stream like worker bees in and out of the subterranean entrance on Eastern Parkway in Brooklyn. Those exiting scatter across Crown Heights to prepare for the Sabbath -- Shabbos in Yiddish -- many drawn a block east by the
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | CROWN HEIGHTS; Where Every Bouquet Tells a Story

body: PERHAPS the only things more varied and numerous than the New York lottery games one can throw money at are regular players' strategies for choosing numbers. Whether it's Powerball or Take 5 or Mega Millions, everyone seems to have a surefire method. Some rely on dreams to furnish numbers; others consult the license plates of parked, or passing,
title: Calculating Luck

body: 'TO THE MOON' Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, isn't likely to replace Cape Canaveral as a permanent launching site for spacecraft. But on Monday it will serve as a blastoff point for several extraterrestrial adventures. They make up ''To the Moon: Short Films About Space Travel,'' the latest program in the Brooklyn series Big Movies for Little Kids. The
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: A 23-year-old man who was facing charges in a killing in SoHo was himself shot to death near Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Wednesday night, the police said. The man, Julio Locarno, had been released from Rikers Island on bail last week. He had been jailed after prosecutors charged him as an accomplice in the killing of an off-duty city medical
title: Man Facing Homicide Charge Is Shot Dead in Brooklyn

body: Scruffy's DNA was harvested in 2008 from a sample of burnt tissue found in the Brooklyn apartment where teenagers doused him with lighter fluid and set him aflame. Madea's was found on the plastic guard of the umbrella that her owner's son-in-law used to fatally club her in 2009. This month, the two cats won a sort of high-tech posthumous justice,
title: CITY ROOM; Animals' DNA Is Used to Win Convictions of Abusers

body: THE bar at Soho House was hopping as those in the members-only crowd clinked glasses and regaled one another at a midlevel roar. But the real drama was playing out one floor down, in the club's library, where a small cross-section of New York City was held rapt by tales seldom overheard in polite company: love disintegrating amid differences in
title: All Around Town, Stories Well Told

body: The man accused of a violent 28-hour rampage through Brooklyn and Manhattan last week was indicted Friday on murder charges. Ken Taub, the chief of the Brooklyn district attorney's homicide bureau, announced the indictments against the man, Maksim Gelman, in Criminal Court in Brooklyn. Mr. Gelman was not present in court. After the court
title: A Suspect in a Killing Spree Is Indicted in Four Murders

body: 'CIRCUS INCOGNITUS' Jamie Adkins, an old-style vaudeville performer, won't mind if you throw things at him during his show. He wants you to throw. He invites you to throw. He'll even provide the things. That Mr. Adkins behaves this way in front of children at the New Victory Theater attests to his bravery. The elementary school students at one of
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Along a freight train line that winds through Brooklyn and Queens, desolate areas are used as gathering spots or refuges for minor outlaws: graffiti painters, drug users and those who camp out with little more than a piece of cardboard, a blanket and a bottle of vodka to keep them company. In one spot, beneath an overpass on Ocean Avenue in
title: Beneath an Overpass, Hints of a Suspect's Obsession

body: He sat in the emergency room at Brookdale University Hospital and Medical Center in Brooklyn, thankful he was alive after being ambushed by a stranger who seemed set on killing him. The unprovoked knife attack left Fitz Fullerton with gashes to his face, hand and neck, requiring dozens of stitches. He did not know then that his attacker was
title: Stabbed in Rampage, Brooklyn Cabdriver Is Then Put in Jail

body: Around 3 p.m. Sunday, John James, twin brother of the longtime president of the National Arts Club, O. Aldon James Jr., hailed a taxicab on West 25th Street in Chelsea and directed the cabby to the club's Victorian mansion on Gramercy Park South, where he keeps an apartment. Mr. James, preparing for a trip to his country home in Maryland, dashed
title: At Arts Club, an Honest Cabby Is Rewarded

body: It was Saturday, shortly after 9 a.m.: Joseph Lozito was on his way to work at Lincoln Center. He took a seat near the front of an uptown No. 3 train at Pennsylvania Station. Two officers entered with him. He barely noticed as they stepped inside the motorman's cab. Then, he said, a third man -- 6 feet tall and dressed in street clothes -- walked
title: Before Fatal Rampage, Some Saw Warning Signs: A Day Like Any Other, Shattered in a Knife-Flash

body: A fugitive with a knife, who the police said had left behind a calamity of murders and broken lives in Brooklyn, was captured by officers at Times Square on Saturday morning after stabbing another victim on a subway train, investigators said. It was the culmination of a roller-coaster of violence that included three fatal stabbings; a hit-and-run
title: CITY ROOM; Suspect in Four Killings Is Captured in Subway

body: THIS month, a raucous hearing on citywide school closings offered the spectator a little bit of everything, including one parent who criticized the city's take on education reform by singing her own lyrics to the tune of Sam Cooke's ''Wonderful World.'' (''They know a lot about charter schools, and they think that merit pay is cool.'') Two members
title: CITYROOM; At a School Set to Close, a Student Has a Voice but No Vote

body: With no snow for days, and none in the immediate forecast, the city is moving out of its period of being buried, which began the day after Christmas and never seemed to end. But as the snow melts, and as city officials tally the cost of this record-breaking winter, other price tags are becoming clear -- whether they be financial, emotional, even
title: Crime Down, Bills Up: How Snow Affects the City

body: Several paintings from Gauguin's Tahitian period will probably be missing from a major exhibition of his work at the National Gallery of Art in Washington when it opens this month, as will a canvas in that museum's coming show on the Venetian painter Canaletto and his rivals. At the Metropolitan Museum of Art a small but important exhibition of
title: Dispute Derails Art Loans From Russia

body: Charisma Massey and her friend did not feel threatened when a black car pulled up alongside them as they walked to the corner store in their Crown Heights, Brooklyn, neighborhood one day in October. Not until they heard the gunshots. The two girls ran, unharmed, and raced for home. Fortunately, the car did not follow. Charisma, 17, said she was
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Gang Threats and Family Ills

body: A GROWN man leapt to his feet and screamed. Sean Crowley had just announced that Snooki, one of the exquisitely tanned stars of MTV's ''Jersey Shore,'' would not be descending to earth in a transparent ball in Times Square on New Year's Eve. (The event was moved to New Jersey.) This meant that the answer to a question Mr. Crowley had posed was
title: Q. Where To Bend Elbow And Mind?

body: BRAINFEST! If you visit the American Museum of Natural History on Saturday, don't be surprised if someone tosses a brick at you or drops a ruler on your toes. It's all in the name of science. The bricks, actually soft synthetics, illustrate how the brain uses past experience to interpret sensory information. ''We're going to show visitors an actual
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Disease seems to be stalking Norma Hedgepeth's family. ''I'm an emotional roller coaster,'' she said one evening, wiping away tears as her husband and niece -- who are both fighting cancer -- looked on. The family of three is unusually tightknit, perhaps because they have all endured hardship. Kenneth Gresham, 52, Ms. Hedgepeth's husband for the
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Surrounded by Cancer, and Then Needing Help Herself

body: Sixty children in a first-grade class can get loud -- sometimes too loud for a teacher to explain a lesson. So while waiting for her teacher to come by, one little girl arranged the pennies she had been given to practice subtraction into a smiley face. Another shook her pennies in a plastic bag. A high-pitched argument broke out over someone's
title: 60 First Graders, 4 Teachers, One Loud New Way to Learn

body: As Wal-Mart battles to open its first stores in New York City, the City Council will hold a hearing on Wednesday on the possible impact to local businesses and communities. Wal-Mart will not participate. Instead, the retail giant has kicked off an intense media campaign, with direct mail, advertisements and a Web site, to get its message to New
title: Wal-Mart Will Skip Hearing By Council

body: CROWN HEIGHTS TOWN HOUSE $449,000 BROOKLYN: 694 Maple Street (between Albany and Troy Avenues) A 15-foot-wide house with three bedrooms, one and a half baths, two basement-level studio apartments, and parking in back. Michael Ettelson, Mordechai Werde, Prudential Douglas Elliman (718) 486-4469; www.elliman.com TAXES: $2,465 a year PROS: The house
title: ON THE MARKET

body: A 26-year-old baby sitter was charged on Friday with murdering a 3-month-old Queens infant whose widely publicized death was initially tied to delays in medical treatment during a blizzard last month. The infant, Addison Reinoso-Xoyatla, lost consciousness on Dec. 29 at his family's home in Corona, Queens, and was taken to Elmhurst Hospital Center,
title: Baby Sitter Is Charged in Death of Infant

body: David G. Trager, a federal judge in Brooklyn whose rulings were pivotal in a racially charged case in Crown Heights and in the first civil suit to challenge the Bush administration's practice of sending terrorism suspects to countries that employ torture, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 73. The cause was pancreatic cancer, his
title: David G. Trager, 73, Judge in Crown Heights Case, Dies

body: OUIGI THEODORE, the founder of the Brooklyn Circus, a retro-urban fashion boutique and label, has heard it all before: dandy, preppy, Anglophile, fop. Still, he was flummoxed when a customer walked into his boutique a year ago, took one look at the bow ties and straw boaters for sale, and declared it the height of ''steampunk.'' Mr. Theodore, 35,
title: UP CLOSE; The Bearded Dandy of Brooklyn
